comment: What to say? Nine moves of "book" so far, and we ain't even got started yet. I don't know if anybody still bothers to think about these things conceptually, but it has always helped me to remind myself at this point why I am sacking a pawn. Right, it clears the 'b' and 'c' files and the h8-a1, h7-b1 diagonals, all of which lead to white's king. Sounds good...
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player, highlighting the strategic purpose of the move to clear defensive lines around the king.
moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 O-O 8. Qd2 Nc6 9. O-O-O d5
context: This is a game between Schneider, Igor (as White) and Hartwig, Thomas (as Black). Last move played: Black plays Pawn to d5
reformulated: Schneider (as White) just played a move that might not seem very aggressive at first glance. The decision to move the pawn to d5 could be questioned since it doesn't immediately challenge the center or create significant threats. The primary advantages of this move are the clear lines it opens for the 'b' and 'c' files, as well as the h8-a1 diagonal, all of which could potentially become routes for White's king. However, since this is still early in the game, there's room to consider whether these benefits are worth the pawn's sacrifice or if there's a better move on the board right now.

comment: 14...Qb8 is also interesting. 14...Qb7 had been scoring badly at the top level recently, but that kind of cutting-edge theory rarely filters down to affect my games. Basically I had played this for a long time, and I had never gotten burnt, so I didn't see any reason to fix it. For all I know however, this is the losing blunder according to Deeper Blue.
reasoning: The comment provides insight into the player's reasoning behind the move, acknowledging the potential mistake but also expressing their familiarity and comfort with the move, as well as the lack of its occurrence in their games at the top level.
moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 g6 6. Be3 Bg7 7. f3 O-O 8. Qd2 Nc6 9. O-O-O d5 10. Nxc6 bxc6 11. exd5 Nxd5 12. Nxd5 cxd5 13. Qxd5 Qc7 14. Qc5 Qb7
context: This is a game between Schneider, Igor (as White) and Hartwig, Thomas (as Black). Last move played: Black plays Queen to b7
reformulated: '14...Qb8 isn't a bad play. 14...Qb7 has shown poor results at chess's highest levels, but such advanced theory seldom impacts games at our level. Because I've used this move for a long time without issue, I didn't see any need to change it. It's possible, though, that this is a mistake, as per Deeper Blue's analysis.'

comment: So far we had both used something like a minute, but I am almost sure that after this move black has inadequate compensation. Sloppy preparation and sloppy form at the board (I should have slowed down and at least considered 17...Bxd3 at this point) cost me the game.
reasoning: This comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player, highlighting the lack of compensation for the move and the importance of careful consideration, specifically pointing out the missed opportunity with 17...Bxd3.

comment: Here I rushed past another critical point. It seemed to me that I had to force c2-c4 to have a chance attacking white's king, so I assumed that 19...Qc6 20.Qb2 was good for white.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player, as they rushed to play c2-c4 without considering other strategic options or potential threats from the opponent.

comment: So I had forced c2-c4, developed my pieces, now what to do? If things went ideally, now I would buckle down and find the winning combination. Instead my 30 minute think produced nothing at all. This is the most depressing kind of loss, when you don't even get a chance to play.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains that the player made a mistake by not finding a winning combination after developing their pieces, resulting in a loss without any play-off opportunity.
